title: Un probleme de cultures ou de culture?: La statue-reliquaire et lesjoca de Sainte Foy de Conques dans le Liber miraculorum de Bernard d'Angers
Though not limited to early medieval art, this book is full of fascinating evidence about the production of medieval manuscripts
The An of Medieval Spain, A.D. 500-1200

Catalogue of an exhibition organized by the Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York, but unfortunately never held. Spanish material plays only a small part in my book owing to lack of space, but the early medieval pictorial tradition there was rich, varied, and extremely interesting because of the interaction of Christianity and Islam

container-title: The Golden Age of Anglo-Saxon An
title: The Lindisfarne Gospels
This is a concise, affordable, and extremely well illustrated monograph on this important manuscript
This is a well-illustrated catalogue of a British Museum exhibition
Icon: Studies in the History of an Idea
Although not dealing directly with the early medieval West, this book provides a useful introduction to classical, late antique, and Byzantine image theory
The Early Middle Ages from Late Antiquity to A.D. 1000
A volume in the well-illustrated Taschen's World Architecture series, this book has many color plates of what remains of early medieval architecture as well as a reliable text
Likeness and Presence: A History of the Image Before the Era of Art

In this broad-ranging study of the image in the Middle Ages, emphasizing the cult of icons and their use in Christian ritual, Belting argues (as the polemic subtitle indicates) that the medieval image was not art in the modern sense
The Cult of the Saints: Its Rise and Function in Latin Christianity
This remarkable study of the origin of the medieval cult of saints and relics indicates the continuities and especially the breaks with the classical tradition
Illuminated Books of the Middle Ages

The first five chapters of this book concern early medieval manuscripts. Particular attention is paid to the insular gospel books, the Vivian Bible, Charles the Bald's Codex aureus, and the Drogo Sacramentary
Burial Ground of Kings?
This accessible treatment of Sutton Hoo is written by the current excavator
Carolingian and Romanesque Architecture 800 to 1200
Although somewhat outdated, this is nevertheless one of the few scholarly treatments of early medieval architecture in English
Early Medieval Art, 300-1150
The selections included here of early medieval texts about art are both interesting and useful
The Pictorial Arts of the West, 800-1200
In this well-illustrated introduction to medieval manuscript illumination and wall painting, the author's focus is almost entirely on the history of style
The Poetry and Paintings of the First Bible of Charles the Bald
This book painstakingly reconstructs the precise historical situation in which the Vivian Bible was made
The Barbarian Conversion from Paganism to Christianity
Fletcher presents a recent, general historical study of the period under consideration in my book

note: Watt, "The Consequences of Literacy" (27-68) and Goody's "Restricted Literacy in Northern Ghana" (198-264).
title: Literacy in Traditional Societies
Particularly important in this series of studies of the role of literacy in traditional societies (such as that of early medieval Europe) are the pathbreaking essay by Goody and I
Early Medieval Painting from the Fourth to the Eleventh Century
Nordenfalk's section has been reprinted as Early Medieval Book Illumination
This sometimes detailed introduction to early medieval wall painting and manuscript illumination is useful and well illustrated

note: The difficult problem of interpreting the Durrow, Lindisfarne, and Kells Gospels is given a thorough, intelligent treatment here.
title: The Forms and Orders of Western Liturgy from the Tenth to the Eighteenth Century
This clear and complete guide to the Christian liturgy is more useful for nonspecialists than J. Jungmann's classic two-volume study, The Mass of the Roman Rite
From Durrow to Kells: The Insular Gospel-books 650-800
Vision and Image in Early Christian England
Henderson presents an interesting cultural study of the art produced in England in the first two centuries after the conversion of the Anglo-Saxons to Christianity

note: it is profusely illustrated with both familiar and unfamiliar works of art.
title: The Carolingian Renaissance
Although a bit outdated, this is still the most solid and comprehensive English-language introduction to Carolingian art
Europe of the Invasions
This companion volume to the authors' The Carolingian Renaissance covers a wide and interesting range of material from late antiquity to the Carolingian period
Byzantine An in the Making: Main Lines of Stylistic Development in Mediterranean Art, Third-Seventh Century
This is an exceptionally subtle and sophisticated consideration of the significance of style in late antique and early medieval Mediterranean art
With primary emphases on style and technique, the author gives a solid, well-illustrated treatment of art used in the service of the Christian liturgy
Gregory the Great and His World
This is an authoritative, recent account of Gregory and his context
The Coming of Christianity to Anglo-Saxon England
The history of the conversion of England to Christianity is presented in a reliable, readable text
Ottoman Book Illumination: An Historical Study

Written by a historian, this book emphasizes the historico-political context of Ottoman illuminated manuscripts; it is richly illustrated and one of the rare detailed treatments of the subject in English
Carolingian Culture: Emulation and Innovation
These useful essays on most facets of Carolingian culture are scholarly but accessible
This essential text gives comprehensive, up-to-date scholarly essays on all aspects of early medieval history with thorough bibliographies
The Book of Durrow
This is an inexpensive and widely available edition with color reproductions of all the decorated pages
Carolingian Painting
This is a reliable introduction to the subject, with many color reproductions
Approaches to Early-Medieval Art
This series of seven essays and an editor's introduction first appeared in Speculum 72
Although the individual essays are quite narrowly focused, as a whole they provide a good introduction to many of the problems involved in the study of early medieval art
The Northumbrian Renaissance: A Study in the Transmission of Style
This discussion of art made in northern England in the seventh and eighth centuries is reliable and thorough
Celtic and Anglo-Saxon Painting
This is a generally reliable introduction with many color illustrations

note: and 4, "Writing Restructures Consciousness," are particularly relevant.
title: Orality and Literacy: The Technologizing of the Word
In this, the best single account of the effects of literacy on the human mind, chapters 3, "Some Psycho dynamics of Orality
Book Illumination in the Middle Ages: An Introduction
Medieval book illumination is given an interesting, thematic treatment; particularly relevant is chapter 2, "The Initial
Gall in Brief
This abridgment of W. Horn and E. Bern's three-volume study of a remarkable, detailed plan of a Carolingian monastery is a good introduction both to early medieval building and to monasticism
The Formation of the Medieval West: Studies in the Oral Culture of the Barbarians
The evidence for early medieval oral culture is assembled and assessed

note: an important subject treated only peripherally in my book.
title: Heaven on Earth: Art and the Church in Byzantium
Although the essays in this collection on Byzantine art were written by leading specialists, they are intended for the general reader and form a good introduction to Byzantine art
Monuments of Romanesque Art
Despite the title, this book includes Carolingian, Ottoman, and Anglo-Saxon art; it is methodologically out of date but still valuable for the hundreds of photographs, including many details

note: with special attention to Carolingian material.
title: The Utrecht Psalter in Medieval Art: Picturing the Psalms of David
This exhibition catalogue is a thorough introduction to early medieval Psalter illustration, both East and West
The Making of England: Anglo-Saxon Art and Culture, AD 600-900
This fine, well-illustrated catalogue of a British Museum exhibition also contains excellent introductory essays

note: This is a reliable, very well illustrated treatment.
title: Anglo-Saxon Art from the Seventh Century to the Norman Conquest
The Work of Angels": Masterpieces of Celtic Metalwork, Sixth-Ninth Centuries AD
This catalogue of an exhibition of Celtic metalwork contains both ecclesiastical and secular art
